desc: An aroma is a scent or smell.
exam: I love the aroma of coffee in the morning.

desc: A beverage is a drink.
exam: The waiter brought our beverages first. Then he brought our food.

desc: A cluster of things is a small group of them placed close together.
exam: She held a large cluster of grapes in her hand.

desc: To combine is to join together to make a single thing or group.
exam: Mina combined peanut butter and jelly to make a sandwich.

desc: When a liquid is condensed, it is made thicker.
exam: One way to make a dessert thick and sweet is to use condensed milk.

desc: When something is contemporary, it is related to the present time.
exam: Contemporary scientists have learned quite a bit about DNA.

desc: To cultivate plants is to care for them and help them grow.
exam: A research company is cultivating new kinds of rice to aid poor countries.

desc: When something is divine, it is related to gods.
exam: Legends say that music was given to men as a divine gift from the gods.

desc: When it is humid, there is a lot of water in the air.
exam: It is very humid inside of a sauna.

desc: An odor is a very distinct smell.
exam: He knew there was a leak when he noticed the strong odor of natural gas.

desc: The palate is the top part of the mouth.
exam: You can touch your palate with your tongue.

desc: Paradise is the place or condition of happiness where things are perfect.
exam: My vacation in Hawaii was like being in paradise.

desc: A plantation is a big farm that only grows certain kinds of crops.
exam: In the 1800s, there were many cotton plantations in the southern US.

desc: When something is rapid, it moves or changes very quickly.
exam: His mother was surprised by her son’s rapid growth.

desc: A rate is the speed at which something happens.
exam: Grass tends to grow at a very slow rate.

desc: When something is soothing, it makes you calm or relaxed.
exam: The soothing music helped the baby fall asleep.

desc: When something is subtle, it is not easy to see or notice.
exam: The handsome man has a subtle smile.

desc: The texture of something is the way its surface looks and feels.
exam: The texture of a rock found in the water is typically very smooth.

desc: When something is toxic, it is poisonous. Toxic things are very dangerous.
exam: Please check the label to see if the product is toxic.

desc: To vary means to be different from another thing in size or amount.
exam: The heights of the people in my class vary by a large amount.

desc: An accident is an unexpected undesirable event.
exam: She had to go to the hospital after she was in a serious car accident.

desc: An admiral is someone who controls many military ships.
exam: They won the sea battle because of the admiral’s great leadership.

desc: An arc is a curved shape.
exam: A rainbow has the shape of an arc.

desc: Your character is your personality.
exam: My sister’s character is fun and very outgoing.

desc: Your conscience is your inner sense of what is right and wrong.
exam: I recycle everything I can, so my conscience is clear!

desc: If something is fiery, it is burning strongly.
exam: The fiery blaze burned all night long.

desc: Flesh is the skin, muscle and fat on your body.
exam: The zebra’s flesh has black and white stripes.

desc: A grapefruit is a fruit similar to an orange, but bigger and not as sweet.
exam: Would you like a grapefruit with your breakfast?

desc: Hay is dry grass used to feed animals or used as a covering.
exam: I need to buy some more hay for the horse to sleep on.

desc: If you are horrified, you are very shocked and feel upset.
exam: I was horrified when I read about the old lady who was attacked.

desc: Kerosene is a type of oil. It is used in some lamps and stoves.
exam: Many people in poor countries cook on kerosene stoves.

desc: A loop is a line made into the shape of a circle.
exam: He made a loop with the rope and placed it over the post.

desc: A paddle is a piece of wood or plastic that moves a boat across water.
exam: We need a paddle to help us move across the water.

desc: A raft is a floating platform made from pieces of wood tied together.
exam: The man made a raft out of bamboo and floated out to sea.

desc: When something is sour, it has a sharp and unpleasant taste.
exam: I don’t like lemons because I think they are too sour.

desc: A stake is a small, sharp piece of wood or metal that is put into the ground.
exam: We marked our property by placing stakes into the ground.

desc: A steward is a person like a waiter who serves food on planes and ships.
exam: The steward is bringing some tea.

desc: String is a thin piece of fabric or rope.
exam: I found a large ball of string.

desc: A thorn is a sharp part of a plant.
exam: Be careful of the thorns when you pick the roses!

desc: To wreck something means to destroy or ruin it.
exam: The teenagers wrecked the house for no reason at all.

desc: To admonish someone is to tell them you disapprove of their behavior.
exam: The teacher admonished Mark because he was chewing gum in class.

desc: If something is audible, then it is able to be heard.
exam: The sound of the drums was audible from miles away.

desc: If something or someone is awesome, they are impressive or frightening.
exam: The huge military plane was an awesome sight.

desc: To beware means to be careful of something or someone that is dangerous.
exam: You should beware of driving fast on wet roads.

desc: To brag means to talk of one’s abilities or achievements in a proud way.
exam: He had strong muscles and bragged about it to the entire class.

desc: If someone is conscious of something, then they are aware of it.
exam: The new student was conscious of the other students staring at her.

desc: To disagree with someone means to have a different opinion from them.
exam: The lawyers disagreed about the best way to settle the case.

desc: To echo means that a sound repeats itself because it bounced off an object.
exam: The child yelled over the canyon, and the wall echoed the sound.

desc: If something is eventual, it will happen at the end of a series of events.
exam: The constant training and planning led the team to an eventual victory.

desc: A hint is information that suggests something will happen or is true.
exam: I quietly passed on a hint to my sister about the test.

desc: An idiot is a person who is not smart or who has done something silly.
exam: Because he got lost in the forest, the man felt like an idiot.

desc: If something is immense, it is very large.
exam: An immense amount of money was needed to buy such a large boat.

desc: If something is indirect, then it is not the easiest or straightest way.
exam: He chose to take the most indirect route to the coast.

desc: An option is a choice between two or more things.
exam: The children were given the option of three houses to pick from.

desc: A pastime is an activity done for fun that you do often.
exam: In the US, baseball is considered the national pastime.

desc: If something is perfect, then it is without any mistakes.
exam: She got all the questions right, so her score was perfect.

desc: To pinpoint something means to locate it exactly.
exam: The navigation system in my car is able to pinpoint my exact location.

desc: To switch means to change something to something else.
exam: Mom switched the TV station from the news to her favorite show.

desc: If something or someone is thorough, then they are complete in every way.
exam: Tina did a thorough job of cleaning the stains out of the carpet.

desc: To torment someone means to cause them to suffer on purpose.
exam: She tormented her little brother by taking his favorite toy.

desc: A beak is the hard curved part of a bird’s mouth.
exam: The bird used her beak to dig a small hole in the ground.

desc: If something is damp, it is somewhat wet.
exam: My hair is still damp from my shower.

desc: To disapprove of something is to think that it is wrong.
exam: Alex, disapproved of his son’s behavior.

desc: You use except to talk about the only thing that a statement does not apply to.
exam: Everyone had fun on the trip except Jim, who felt ill the whole time.

desc: A flight is an act of flying, often in an airplane.
exam: The airplane made a flight around the world.

desc: When someone is fond of something, they like it.
exam: I am very fond of chocolate cake.

desc: When something or someone is immoral, they are evil or do bad things.
exam: Stealing money from one’s mother is an immoral act.

desc: Ivy is a plant with long vines that grows upward typically on walls.
exam: The walls of the castle are covered with ivy.

desc: To moan is to make a low sound when feeling pain or sadness.
exam: The sick man moaned from his bed.

desc: If someone is oblivious of something, they are unaware of it.
exam: I was late to school because I was oblivious of the time.

desc: To perish means to die, usually because of bad conditions or bad events.
exam: Many people perish in wars.

desc: A pit is a big hole in the ground.
exam: Michael fell into the pit and needed some help to get out.

desc: The rim is the outside edge of a round thing, like a cup or bottle.
exam: I put my lips to the rim of the bottle and took a drink.

desc: A roost is a place where birds can land and rest or sleep.
exam: The family of doves made a roost at the top of the tree.

desc: If something is slippery, it is wet or smooth and causes people to slip.
exam: The repairman fell down on the floor because it was too slippery.

desc: To soar means to fly high in the air.
exam: As the sun rose, two eagles soared through the sky.

desc: If something is trivial, it is not important or meaningful.
exam: Television is trivial, but learning to read is very important.

desc: If something is typical, it is normal for a certain type of thing.
exam: Barking is typical behavior for dogs.

desc: If something is utterly a way, it is completely that way.
exam: When the sun was blocked by the moon, it was utterly dark outside.

desc: To weep means to cry.
exam: My sister told me the dramatic movie would make me weep.

desc: If you do something awhile, you do it for a short time.
exam: Wait here awhile, and I’ll bring some tea.

desc: Cyberspace is the imaginary place of the Internet where activities occur.
exam: I didn’t receive your email. It probably got lost in cyberspace.

desc: To edit means to correct a piece of writing so that it is suitable to be published.
exam: She asked her brother to edit her paper before she submitted it to her teacher.

desc: An essay is a short piece of writing on a certain subject.
exam: She had to write a two-page essay for her English class.

desc: To evaluate something means to study it, so a decision can be made.
exam: Joe and Ken evaluated the plan and agreed that it would work.

desc: To faint means to go unconscious and fall down.
exam: Carol fainted because she hadn’t eaten in over a day.

desc: If something is global, it happens all around the world.
exam: Pollution is a global problem.

desc: A gymnasium is a building with equipment that you can use to get exercise.
exam: When I go to the gymnasium, I use the treadmill for 20 minutes.

desc: To highlight something means to mark it with a color so that it is easy to see.
exam: I read my vocabulary list and highlighted the most difficult words.

desc: If someone is ignorant about something, they have no knowledge about it.
exam: I’m a bit ignorant about his theories. Can you explain them to me?

desc: An index is a list of words at the end of a book that gives information.
exam: If you look in the index, you’ll find the right page number.

desc: A lecture is a long, educational speech.
exam: His lecture on world hunger was very informative.

desc: A moral is a message at the end of a story that teaches you something.
exam: At the end of the story, Mother explained the moral to the children.

desc: To operate means to work or function.
exam: I’m sorry, but the trains are not operating today.

desc: If something is private, it is only used by one person or group.
exam: Don’t look at my diary! It’s private!

desc: When something is recent, it happened a short time ago.
exam: I did not know what caused his recent behavior.

desc: A resolution is a personal decision.
exam: At New Year, I made a list of resolutions to help me have a better year.

desc: A semester is a portion of a school year.
exam: Jack is in his second semester of college.

desc: If something is typewritten, it is written on a computer or typewriter.
exam: This is an important, formal project and must be typewritten.

desc: When something is weird, it is very strange.
exam: My best friend’s dad is a bit weird.

desc: If something is absolute, it is total or complete.
exam: My presentation was an absolute disaster! It was terrible!

desc: Alas is a word that people say when something bad happens.
exam: I looked everywhere for my purse, but alas, I couldn’t find it.

desc: If you are attentive, you are careful and you pay attention.
exam: He is a good student because he is attentive to every detail on his work.

desc: A cape is a large cloth that covers one’s back and is tied around the neck.
exam: The superhero wore a long red cape.

desc: To envision something means to imagine that it may happen.
exam: I can envision my mom’s face when I give her this present!

desc: When something happens evenly, it happens at the same rate or level.
exam: The food was handed out evenly among the hungry people.

desc: Folk are common or average people.
exam: I’ve invited all the folks from our street to a gathering at my place.

desc: To melt means to turn from a solid to a liquid.
exam: The snowman that we made yesterday melted in the sun.

desc: A patch is a part of a surface that is different in appearance from the rest.
exam: There was one small patch of grass in the sand-covered desert.

desc: Pleasure is a feeling of happiness.
exam: The student smiled with pleasure when she received the prize.

desc: A pop is a short, loud sound.
exam: I heard a loud pop; then my computer screen shattered.

desc: A pudding is a sweet dessert.
exam: Would you like some chocolate pudding and coffee for dessert?

desc: A rail is a horizontal bar made of metal or wood.
exam: The cat was sitting on the rail of the fence.

desc: A recipe is a set of instructions to make food.
exam: The apple cake that you made is really tasty. Can I have the recipe, please?

desc: A role is the normal purpose or function of a person or thing.
exam: My role at work is to check the quality of the products.

desc: To shrink means to get smaller.
exam: If you stick to a healthy diet, your stomach will shrink!

desc: To soak something means to make it very wet.
exam: You need to soak these beans overnight before you cook them.

desc: A spark is a small, quick flash of fire.
exam: As he welded the two pieces of metal together, sparks flew everywhere.

desc: A spirit is someone’s feelings and personality, but not a physical body part.
exam: He has a very outgoing spirit. He can make friends with anyone.

desc: A suit is a set of clothes. It usually includes a jacket with pants or a skirt.
exam: I wore my new suit on my date with Melissa.

desc: An account with a bank is an arrangement to keep one’s money there.
exam: After I paid for the new car, my bank account was nearly empty.

desc: An architect is a person who designs buildings.
exam: The plans for building the new home were drawn by a famous architect.

desc: To conceal something means to hide it.
exam: You should conceal your money so no one can take it from you.

desc: A crime is something bad that a person does that can be punished by law.
exam: Police quickly arrived at the scene of the crime.

desc: A deed is a certificate that proves that someone owns something.
exam: When she bought the car, she was given a deed to show the car was hers.

desc: Gratitude is a feeling of being thankful.
exam: The kids showed Aunt Tess much gratitude for visiting them.

desc: A habitat is the natural home of animals or plants.
exam: Frogs are often found in a wet habitat, such as near a lake, river, or pond.

desc: To intervene means to help stop a problem between two people or groups.
exam: The students argued until the teacher intervened.

desc: A landmark is an object that helps people find or remember a location.
exam: The tall tree was used as a landmark for people to find the road to the inn.

desc: If something is legal, it is related to the law or allowed by the law.
exam: It was not legal for him to drive until he was eighteen years old.

desc: If something is memorable, then it is remembered for a special reason.
exam: The party was memorable; people were still talking about it years later.

desc: To oblige someone means to require them to do something.
exam: If I wanted to have playtime, I was obliged to clean my room once a week.

desc: An offense is an action that breaks the law and requires punishment.
exam: He was put in jail for two days for the offense.

desc: To proclaim something means to say it in public.
exam: The army general proclaimed that the war was won.

desc: A rally is a large public meeting in order to support something.
exam: The school had a rally in the gym to support the basketball team.

desc: To resolve something means to find a solution.
exam: She resolved the problem with her children by giving them both a toy.

desc: Resources are a person or country’s money and materials that they can use.
exam: The poor man didn’t have the resources to feed himself.

desc: A sentence is punishment given to someone who didn’t follow the law.
exam: The sentence for stealing a car is much worse than for stealing candy.

desc: To volunteer means to offer to do something for free.
exam: Many people volunteered to help the adults learn to read.

desc: A witness is someone who sees or hears a crime or accident happen.
exam: The woman was the only witness of the horrible crime.

desc: Access is the right to enter or use something.
exam: The manager was the only person with access to the password.

desc: Conduct is the way that someone acts.
exam: She was punished for her bad conduct.

desc: When an event or action is constant, it happens a lot or all the time.
exam: The television at home is in constant use.

desc: A crack is a narrow space between the parts of something broken.
exam: The old window was covered with cracks.

desc: A device is an object or a machine.
exam: A thermometer is a device that tells temperature.

desc: To enclose something is to contain it.
exam: The cows in the field were enclosed by a fence.

desc: To grip something is to hold it very tightly.
exam: I was scared, so I gripped my older sister’s hand.

desc: To halt is to stop moving.
exam: The criminal halted when he saw the police coming.

desc: If something is impending, it is going to happen soon.
exam: The student was nervous about his impending test.

desc: To influence someone or something is to have an effect over them.
exam: My friend influenced my decision to attend Terrance University.

desc: A law is a rule made by the legislative body.
exam: The students learned about different laws during social studies class.

desc: A mode is a setting or condition on a machine.
exam: Mother turned the TV to quiet mode while she talked on the phone.

desc: To perspire means to sweat.
exam: I usually perspire a lot when I am at practice.

desc: To replace something is to put it in the place of something else.
exam: I replaced the tire on my car because it was flat.

desc: To snap something means to break it suddenly, which causes a loud noise.
exam: I took the stick and snapped it with my hands.

desc: If a person or animal is sly, they are sneaky or good at tricking people.
exam: The sly fox stole the eggs from the nest.

desc: To tend to do something is to be likely to do it or to do it often.
exam: My mom tends to buy me the perfect gift each Christmas.

desc: When something is valid, it is correct or based on good reasoning.
exam: The expert’s opinion on the subject was more valid than others.

desc: A version is an account of something that differs slightly from the original.
exam: She read the students British version of the Chinese fairy tale.

desc: You use whatsoever after a noun to emphasize that there is nothing of that thing.
exam: The boy had no idea whatsoever how to solve the story problem.

desc: If something is alongside another thing, then it is next to it.
exam: We work alongside each other in the office.

desc: Your appetite is your hunger for food.
exam: Tom has a big appetite. He eats all the time.

desc: To assist someone is to help them.
exam: Andrew assisted me with my homework.

desc: A breeze is a soft wind.
exam: The breeze caused the leaves to fall off the tree.

desc: To defy someone is to work against them or refuse to do what they say.
exam: The students got into trouble for defying their teacher’s rules.

desc: To display something is to show it, especially by putting it in a certain place.
exam: The museum displayed many wonderful paintings.

desc: If something or someone is efficient, they do not waste energy.
exam: My car is very efficient. I rarely have to buy gas.

desc: If someone is feeble, they are small or weak.
exam: The boy was too feeble to carry the object very far.

desc: To forgive someone is to stop being angry with them.
exam: Sandra forgave Peter after he said he was sorry.

desc: If someone is lively, they have a lot of energy.
exam: Jennifer is very lively: she’s always running and playing.

desc: If something is majestic, it is large and beautiful.
exam: The rich people lived in a big, majestic house.

desc: You use nor to connect two negative ideas.
exam: I eat neither apples nor oranges. I don’t like either one.

desc: If someone is outraged, they are very angry.
exam: My father was outraged when he saw that I had crashed his car.

desc: If someone is pessimistic, they believe that the worst will happen.
exam: John is pessimistic. He always thinks something bad will happen.

desc: A rumor is something people talk about even though it may not be true.
exam: Kevin was spreading rumors about Marcia to everyone.

desc: To slap someone means to hit them with the palm of the hand.
exam: Out of anger, Helen slapped Eunice on the face.

desc: To smash something is to break it into many small pieces.
exam: Jacob smashed the window with a rock.

desc: A subject is the topic that is being discussed or taught.
exam: The subject of Marco’s speech was the economy.

desc: A wage is the money that a person gets for doing a job.
exam: The wages I receive from my job are really great!

desc: You use whereas to show how two things are different.
exam: My sister loves horror movies, whereas I prefer comedies.

desc: When something is animate, it has life.
exam: Rocks and machines are not animate things.

desc: To classify things is to put them into groups based on their type.
exam: The biologist classified the plant as a completely new species.

desc: To concede is to admit that something is true against your wish.
exam: The student conceded that he had cheated on the test.

desc: A concept is an idea about something.
exam: I learned some concepts of molecules before working in the science lab.

desc: To construct something means to make or build it.
exam: The men used wood and metal to construct a house.

desc: A decade is a period often years.
exam: She celebrated her three decades of work with the company.

desc: A diagram is a simple drawing that explains what something is or how it works.
exam: By following the diagram, I was able to put the desk together.

desc: A ferry is a boat that carries passengers over short distances.
exam: The ferry took the people across the lake.

desc: If something is handy, it is useful.
exam: An eraser is handy if you make a lot of mistakes.

desc: To isolate is to separate one person or thing from a group.
exam: The teacher isolated the bad child from the class before talking with her.

desc: A longing is a strong feeling of wanting.
exam: Since he skipped breakfast, he had a longing for food all morning.

desc: If something is numerous, there are many of those things.
exam: It was hard to drive fast since there were numerous holes in the road.

desc: A particle is a very small piece of something.
exam: The bottles of wine were covered in a layer of dust particles.

desc: A plea is a request that is urgent or emotional.
exam: The poor, hungry man made a plea for food.

desc: To refrain from something is to avoid doing it.
exam: The doctor asked Mary to refrain from eating fast food as part of her diet.

desc: A review of something is a formal inspection of it by people in authority.
exam: The government ordered a careful review of the economic situation.

desc: If someone is sophisticated, they know many things about the world.
exam: Jake is one of the most sophisticated persons I’ve ever met.

desc: To surrender something is to give it up.
exam: The thief surrendered the money to the police when he was caught.

desc: If something is upright, it is standing up straight.
exam: Meerkats can’t walk like humans, but they can stand upright.

desc: If something is worthwhile, it is important or useful.
exam: On his visit to Canada, he realized studying English was worthwhile.

desc: An alliance is a group of people who work together.
exam: The junior executives formed an alliance with each other.

desc: Applause is the noise made when people clap hands to show approval.
exam: At the end of his speech, everyone gave applause.

desc: If you are armed, you are carrying a weapon.
exam: The robber was armed with a gun.

desc: If something is authoritative, it uses the best information available.
exam: This book is an authoritative source on Ancient Egypt’s Queen Nefertiti.

desc: A ceremony is an event that happens on special occasions.
exam: Tom and Amy’s marriage ceremony is in June.

desc: Culture is the music, art, and writings of a certain place or group of people.
exam: Ancient Mexican culture is renowned for its architecture.

desc: A defense is something that is done to protect another thing.
exam: The airforce works in defense of its country.

desc: A detail is a small piece of information.
exam: Jane told Ben all the details of her trip to China.

desc: When a group of things is diverse, it is made up of a wide variety of things.
exam: Big cities have diverse populations with people of different races and ages.

desc: To enchant someone is to make them feel very interested or happy.
exam: The beautiful woman enchanted everybody in the room.

desc: To equip someone is to give them the things needed to do something.
exam: Steve was equipped with the tools needed to do the job.

desc: An exception is someone or something not conforming to a rule.
exam: Most students thought the test was hard, but Tim was the exception.

desc: A genre is a type of literature, art, or music characterized by its style.
exam: She is considered a master in the comedy genre.

desc: An impact is the effect someone or something has on another.
exam: My grandmother had a great impact on my life.

desc: To lure someone is to convince them to do something, by using a trick.
exam: The store lures people in with big signs that say “Sale!”

desc: An obstacle is an object or a problem that stops you from doing something.
exam: Climbing over the giant rock was the biggest obstacle for the hikers.

desc: A shelter is a place to go that is safe from danger or bad weather.
exam: The frog took shelter from the storm in a nearby cave.

desc: To sort means to separate things into different groups or classes.
exam: He sorted his clothes by colors and sizes.

desc: To supply something means to give people what they need or want.
exam: The water heater supplied the house with warm water.

desc: If people are vain, they are only concerned with how they look.
exam: Rebecca is so vain that she looks at herself in every mirror.

desc: An alternative is something that you can choose instead of your first choice.
exam: Her first plan to make extra money seemed weak, so she chose an alternative.

desc: An avenue is a road, often a large one with buildings on each side.
exam: Drive down this avenue and then turn left to go to the park.

desc: The belly is the stomach of a person or animal.
exam: His belly was full because he ate a lot of food.

desc: A bid to do something is an attempt to do it.
exam: He made a bid to become the university’s next president.

desc: To blow means to move air or move something through the air, as in the wind.
exam: The wind is blowing very hard today. We should stay inside.

desc: A conflict is a fight between different people or groups.
exam: The two nations had a conflict over which one could use the water in the river.

desc: A continent is one of the seven large areas of land on the Earth.
exam: Asia is the largest continent.

desc: A current is a steady and constant flow of air or water in a river or ocean.
exam: The ocean currents took the ship far off into the sea.

desc: Disrespect is rudeness or a behavior that shows a lack of respect.
exam: He showed disrespect by arguing with his boss during a meeting.

desc: Enthusiasm is a very strong good feeling about something.
exam: The crowd showed their enthusiasm for the soccer team by cheering loudly.

desc: When something is harsh, it is very unpleasant.
exam: The desert can be a very harsh environment.

desc: To lean is to bend the body in a particular direction.
exam: The woman leaned against the counter because she was tired.

desc: The meantime is the time between two events.
exam: Ted began setting the table. In the meantime, I began preparing the food.

desc: Mischief is behavior that is meant to trick or cause trouble for people.
exam: Ben was up to mischief when he persuaded Ken to paint his face.

desc: Muscle is a mass of tissue attached to bone that helps you move.
exam: She went to the gym in order to make her muscles stronger.

desc: To rescue someone means to remove them from danger.
exam: The firefighter rescued the man from the burning building.

desc: A succession is a number of things that follow one after the other.
exam: The student said the letters of the alphabet in succession.

desc: The terrain is the land and all of its physical features or parts.
exam: The terrain below was rocky and full of hills.

desc: If someone is timid, they are afraid, shy, or nervous.
exam: The timid child hides behind her mother whenever she sees a stranger.

desc: Violence is forceful action that is meant to injure or kill people.
exam: The boy hit his brother in an act of violence.

desc: To affect someone or something is to have an influence over them.
exam: The student’s poor attitude affected the other students in the class.

desc: An autograph is the written name of a famous person.
exam: Everybody wanted the movie star’s autograph.

desc: A bead is a drop of liquid.
exam: Beads of water collected outside the glass.

desc: To brew coffee or tea means to pour hot water over it.
exam: Please brew a fresh pot of coffee.

desc: To charm someone is to please them with your personality.
exam: Gail charmed everyone with her humorous stories.

desc: A destiny is all the things that happen or will happen to a person in their life.
exam: It was his destiny to become a great singer.

desc: A horn is a device that makes a loud noise.
exam: The boy honked his horn while he rode his bicycle past the house.

desc: When someone is irritable, they become annoyed or angry very easily.
exam: She is irritable when she doesn’t get enough sleep.

desc: To lag behind is to move slowly behind other moving objects.
exam: The girl on rollerblades lagged behind the little girl on the bicycle.

desc: To maximize something means to make it the biggest in size or amount.
exam: Businesses try to maximize their profits.

desc: A nightmare is a bad or scary dream.
exam: The girl was scared to go back to sleep because she had a nightmare.

desc: When something is nutritious, it helps the body stay healthy.
exam: Mangoes are one of the most nutritious fruits in the world.

desc: Protein is a substance that is necessary for the body to grow and be strong.
exam: Fish and beef are good sources of protein.

desc: A signature is your name that you have written in your own way.
exam: I put my signature at the end of the letter.

desc: Stuff is a word used to refer to things without mentioning the things by name.
exam: We gave a lot of stuff to the charity.

desc: When something is subconscious, it is done without thinking about it.
exam: Breathing is one of the subconscious things that the body does.

desc: A van is a vehicle that is used for carrying things but is smaller than a truck.
exam: The delivery company uses large vans to deliver packages.

desc: To warn someone is to make them know of possible danger in the future.
exam: The lifeguard warned people to stay away from the rough ocean.

desc: A workout is an exercise routine that helps improve health.
exam: She doesn’t do her workout on the weekends.

desc: To zoom is to move quickly.
exam: The cars zoomed along the road.

desc: A brick is a block of hard clay that is used for building things, such as walls.
exam: There were several bricks scattered on the ground.

desc: To crumble means to break or fall apart into small pieces.
exam: The old house’s walls crumbled into a pile of rock and wood.

desc: Dough is a mixture of flour and water that becomes bread when baked.
exam: I made heart-shaped cookies from the dough.

desc: To express a feeling or idea means to show others how one thinks or feels.
exam: The nurse expressed her sympathy for the sick patient.

desc: A fist is a hand with fingers bent in toward the palm.
exam: The bully made a fist and threatened to hit the small boy.

desc: If something is flexible, then it can bend easily without breaking.
exam: The tree branch was so flexible it could be bent into a circle and not break.

desc: To flush means the face becomes red due to heat, illness, or emotion.
exam: After the long race, the runner’s face was flushed.

desc: To injure someone means to damage a part of their body.
exam: The car crash injured two people.

desc: A lump is a small piece of something that is solid.
exam: The artist took a lump of clay and turned it into a beautiful pot.

desc: A mixture is something that is made by mixing other things together.
exam: The walls were built using a mixture of water, rock, and dirt.

desc: To reconcile means to return to a friendly relationship.
exam: After arguing, the two friends were reconciled with each other.

desc: To ruin something means to harm or damage it greatly.
exam: Our walk in the park was ruined by the sudden rain.

desc: To shatter something means to break it suddenly into many tiny pieces.
exam: When the ball hit the window, the glass shattered.

desc: Shutters are wooden or metal covers in front of a window.
exam: Mr. Smith closed the shutters every night to make his bedroom dark.

desc: To sift something means to remove all the large pieces.
exam: The baker sifted the flour into a large bowl.

desc: If something is slight, then it is small or minor.
exam: There was only a slight change in the little boy’s height.

desc: To sparkle means to shine brightly with quick flashes of light.
exam: The stars sparkled in the winter night’s sky.

desc: To sprinkle means to scatter something all over something else.
exam: He sprinkled the pasta with salt and black pepper.

desc: If food is stale, then it is not fresh but dry, hard, and not good to eat.
exam: The cookies sat on the table so long that they became stale.

desc: To utter a word or a sound means to say it.
exam: The lost boy was so scared that he could barely utter a single word.

desc: You use although to say that one thing is contrasted by another.
exam: Although she was late, her friends gave her a warm welcome.

desc: To apply something means to put it on.
exam: She always applies makeup to her face before going outside.

desc: To await something means to wait for it.
exam: The players awaited the judge’s decision.

desc: When something is beloved, it is very special and you like it very much.
exam: The boy took a nap next to his beloved cat.

desc: To bury someone or something means to put them in the ground.
exam: They buried their grandfather under his favorite tree after he died.

desc: A climate is the usual weather in a place.
exam: The climate in the desert is very hot.

desc: When you complain, you say that you are unhappy about something.
exam: The workers complained that they were being treated unfairly.

desc: To confuse someone means to make them feel like they are unsure.
exam: The sign confused the traveler because it pointed in two directions.

desc: When something is due, it is expected to happen or be done at that time.
exam: The papers were due on the 19th.

desc: When you talk about an entire thing, you are talking about the whole thing.
exam: He was so hungry that he ate the entire pizza by himself.

desc: To establish something means to create it.
exam: He wanted to establish a club for people to help the Earth.

desc: A furnace is a place where heat is made.
exam: Mr. Jones came to fix the furnace.

desc: A leash is a rope or chain that is used to lead an animal.
exam: A lot of dogs must wear a leash to keep them from running away.

desc: To mature means to grow up to become an adult.
exam: When they matured, they became as tall as their parents.

desc: To measure something means to find out the quality, value, or effect of it.
exam: The scientists carefully measured the amount of chemicals in the tubes.

desc: The midst of something is the middle of it.
exam: She was in the midst of cleaning when the telephone rang.

desc: Misery is extreme suffering.
exam: There was a lot of misery after Sam lost his dog.

desc: When something happened prior to something else, it happened earlier.
exam: Ron had to wait since he arrived prior to the scheduled meeting time.

desc: Research is close and careful study to discover new things.
exam: Scientists did a lot of research on the subject of blood type.

desc: A variety of something is a group of many different kinds of it.
exam: There are a variety of flowers at the shop.

desc: If something happens altogether, it happens completely.
exam: The company stopped using sugar altogether in its food.

desc: To bind is to bring people together.
exam: The victims of the flood were bound by their need to help each other.

desc: A bruise is a dark mark caused by being hit by something.
exam: She got a bruise on her knee from falling down.

desc: A custom is a way of doing things that has been the same for a long time.
exam: It is a custom that the bride and groom have the first dance.

desc: When someone is disobedient, they do not follow the rules or instructions.
exam: The disobedient children didn’t listen to their mother and had an accident.

desc: To foresee something is to know about it before it happens.
exam: The teacher didn’t foresee any problems with her large class.

desc: To glimpse something is to see it for a short time.
exam: She glimpsed outside the window as the plane was about to land.

desc: A hoop is a ring that is made of plastic, metal, or wood.
exam: The boys tried to toss the ball through the basketball hoop.

desc: Misfortune is bad luck or an unlucky event.
exam: His family helped him when he encountered misfortune.

desc: When something is negative, it is unpleasant or sad.
exam: She doesn’t like to say negative things about her friends.

desc: Per is used to mean “each” when giving a price, size, or amount.
exam: It costs $8 per person to watch the baseball game.

desc: To plead is to ask for something you want very badly.
exam: He pleaded for his parents to let him go to the soccer game.

desc: To rip something means to pull it apart.
exam: She ripped the paper in half by accident.

desc: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
exam: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.

desc: To scrape something is to rub it very hard with something sharp.
exam: I accidentally scraped the paint off the side of the car.

desc: A source of something is the place that it comes from.
exam: The river was the source of drinking water for the village.

desc: When somebody is stern, they are very serious.
exam: The stern teacher didn’t allow the students to speak during class.

desc: To stitch is to use a needle and thread to join pieces of cloth together.
exam: My grandmother stitched the pieces together to make a big blanket.

desc: A thump is the sound of a heavy object falling.
exam: They heard the thump when the bowling ball hit the floor.

desc: When somebody is vehement, they are angry and emotional.
exam: Gina was vehement when she found out that Liz was bad in school.

desc: A civilization is an organized group of humans that have culture and government.
exam: Most early civilizations in Central America didn’t use metal weapons.

desc: When something is convenient, it is easy to do and does not take a lot of work.
exam: The bus is a convenient way to get to school.

desc: A den is a living space for some types of animals, such as lions.
exam: The mother lion left her babies in the den.

desc: Dew is the drops of water that form on the ground outside during the night.
exam: When we woke up, we saw that the grass was covered in dew.

desc: When something is drastic, it is extreme or major.
exam: She made a drastic decision to get her long hair cut short.

desc: To exit means to leave.
exam: The students exited through the front door.

desc: A flock is a group of animals, such as birds, sheep or goats.
exam: There was one black sheep in the entire flock.

desc: To fold is to bend something like paper or cloth so that it takes up less space.
exam: I folded the paper and put it in my pocket.

desc: A lid is a top for a box or container that can be removed.
exam: He lifted the lid of the box and revealed her present.

desc: To loom is to seem very large and often scary.
exam: The ominous clouds loomed over the school.

desc: When something is mighty, it is strong and large.
exam: The mighty wrestler scared all who faced him.

desc: A mushroom is a fungus with a round top. Some are used as food.
exam: The soup had fresh mushrooms in it.

desc: When something is native, it is originating in a certain place or area.
exam: Avocadoes are native fruits of Mexico.

desc: Poison is a dangerous substance that causes illness or death.
exam: They used poison to get rid of the rats in their home.

desc: Reeds are tall and skinny plants that grow in groups near water.
exam: The sun set behind the reeds of the lake’s shore.

desc: To shield something is to protect it.
exam: She shielded her eyes from the sun with sunglasses.

desc: Stormy describes something affected or characterized by storms.
exam: The golfers decided to go home because of the stormy weather.

desc: To sway is to move slowly from side to side.
exam: She swayed while she listened to the music.

desc: When something is urban, it is related to the city.
exam: Subways are an important form of urban transportation.

desc: To wade is to walk in or pass through water.
exam: The child waded in the water at the beach.

desc: An accent is a certain way of speaking that shows where a person is from.
exam: The new teacher’s accent was clearly a German one.

desc: A barber is a person whose job is to cut hair.
exam: My hair is getting much too long. I’d better go to the barber’s shop.

desc: A basement of a house or building is a room that is built underground.
exam: They turned their basement into a game room.

desc: When something is blank, it does not have anything on it.
exam: She got a blank paper to draw on.

desc: To blink means to shut the eyes and quickly open them again.
exam: I blinked many times so that my eyes could adjust to the bright light.

desc: A choir is a group of people who sing together.
exam: He had choir practice every day after school.

desc: When something is comic, it is funny.
exam: The comic actor was famous for his jokes.

desc: To complicate something means to make it harder than necessary.
exam: The bad weather complicated finishing the job quickly.

desc: To decline an offer or invitation means to say no to it.
exam: She declined his offer to pay for her dinner.

desc: An errand is a trip taken to do a specific activity.
exam: He couldn’t go to practice because he had several errands to do.

desc: A glove is a piece of clothing that covers your fingers and hand.
exam: When it gets cold, I always put on a pair of gloves.

desc: A hermit is one who lives alone and does not spend time with others.
exam: The hermit lived a simple life in a small cave in the forest.

desc: If something is done justly, then it is fair.
exam: We justly decided to give the prize to him.

desc: Leather is a material made from animal skin that is used to make clothing.
exam: He got a new leather jacket for his birthday.

desc: To ponder something is to think about it carefully.
exam: She sat in the park and pondered her problem.

desc: To reserve something means to keep it for a certain person or time.
exam: He reserved a table at the busy restaurant.

desc: A script is the words of a film or play.
exam: He read the script of the play three times.

desc: To search for something or someone means to look for them carefully.
exam: I searched the newspaper for a new job.

desc: To slam is to close something hard.
exam: She slammed the book shut after she finished reading it.

desc: A staircase is a set of stairs found inside a building.
exam: The staircase leads directly into the kitchen.

desc: Afflicted means to suffer physically or mentally.
exam: He was afflicted by pain in his right arm.

desc: An aisle is a space between two things that people use to walk.
exam: They were told to clear the aisle because the plane was about to land.

desc: The atmosphere is the air around the Earth where weather conditions form.
exam: Scientists worry that harmful substances are hurting the atmosphere.

desc: An author is a person who wrote a certain piece of writing.
exam: The author was hard at work on his next novel.

desc: A breakdown is a failure to work correctly.
exam: Her car had a breakdown, and she wasn’t sure how to fix it.

desc: Cargo is the items carried by a ship or airplane.
exam: The cargo of the ship got wet when it started raining.

desc: A chapter is a part of a book that usually has a number or a title.
exam: The first chapter of a book usually introduces the main character of a story.

desc: To connect two things means to join them together.
exam: I connected the mouse to my laptop computer.

desc: Etc. is short for “etcetera.” It is used to refer to other unspecified objects.
exam: She was going to bring treats to the party: cookies, muffins, cake, etc.

desc: To flip means to press a switch quickly to turn it on or off.
exam: To turn on the lights, just flip this switch.

desc: If you are idle, you are not doing anything.
exam: She read a book to keep from being idle.

desc: To notify someone of something is to tell them about it.
exam: The teacher notified us about a change to our assignment.

desc: Peas are a vegetable that is small, round and green.
exam: His favorite food was peas.

desc: A raisin is a dried grape.
exam: Raisins are one of my favorite snacks.

desc: To retain something is to keep it.
exam: Even by the afternoon, the day had retained the morning’s freshness.

desc: To state something means to say it in a definite way.
exam: The president stated his opinion about the world’s health concerns.

desc: A tray is a flat plate used to hold food.
exam: The waiter brought our food on a tray.

desc: If something is unfortunate, it is bad or unlucky.
exam: It was unfortunate that Dave’s team lost, but he still had fun.

desc: When something is vivid, it is bright and colorful.
exam: The figures in the painting were vivid.

desc: To vomit means to have food come up from one’s stomach.
exam: It is common for women to vomit when they are pregnant.

desc: To betray someone means to treat them in a dishonest way.
exam: The man betrayed his country when he gave away national secrets.

desc: A blast is a loud noise made by something that explodes.
exam: There was a loud blast when the police officer fired the gun.

desc: A bracelet is a piece of jewelry that you wear around your wrist.
exam: My father gave me a pretty gold bracelet for my birthday.

desc: To cease means to stop.
exam: After about an hour, the rain ceased, and a rainbow appeared.

desc: To choke means to cough because you have difficulty breathing.
exam: There was a lot of smoke in the air, and it made me choke.

desc: When an event is civil, it happens inside a country.
exam: The country was torn apart by a terrible civil war.

desc: To comment means to say something that shows your personal opinion.
exam: Tom commented on the poor quality of the food.

desc: To cross means to go from one side to the other side.
exam: We used his boat to cross to the other side of the lake.

desc: A dent is damage caused by something heavy hitting something else.
exam: That blue car hit my car, and now there is a small dent in my car door.

desc: To distrust someone means to believe that they are not honest.
exam: Don’t lend money to someone if you distrust them!

desc: A fort is a small building that is specially built to defend an area from attack.
exam: When the army arrived, they built a big fort on the top of the hill.

desc: To found means to bring something into existence.
exam: The pastor founded his church in the countryside.

desc: Lining is a piece of cloth that covers the inside of clothes.
exam: This jacket is very warm because it has a thick lining.

desc: A mass is a large number of things of one type.
exam: We received a mass of letters this morning.

desc: To pray means to talk to God.
exam: When people go to church, they pray for their families and friends.

desc: If a place is rife with something bad, it is very common in that place.
exam: This part of the country is rife with disease.

desc: When something is the sole thing, it is the only thing of a particular type.
exam: His sole purpose in life was to help others.

desc: If you sweep the floor, you clean it with a tool like a broom or a brush.
exam: There is a lot of dirt on the floor. Can you sweep it please?

desc: Treachery is a behavior in which a person betrays a country or a person.
exam: The man ran away to escape from the treachery of his wife.

desc: To tuck something means to put it somewhere so that it is neat or safe.
exam: He looked sloppy without his shirt being tucked into his pants.

desc: A background is a person’s education, family, and experience.
exam: The new teacher had a background in science and math.

desc: Bait is something used to trick a person or thing to do something.
exam: The best bait for catching fish is a big, fat worm.

desc: To chronicle something means to record an event or speech.
exam: The daily newspaper chronicles local and world events.

desc: Copper is a red-brown metal often used in electric wire and pipes.
exam: Ancient hunters melted copper to make knives and spears.

desc: A disease is an illness that causes specific problems.
exam: He had a disease that caused him to lose his hearing.

desc: Folklore is the collection of beliefs and stories of a culture.
exam: India’s folklore has stories written in long poems about great warriors.

desc: To infect someone means to give them an illness.
exam: The common cold infects hundreds of millions of people each year.

desc: To itch means to rub the skin with your fingernails.
exam: The rough fabric in his shirt made the back of his neck itch.

desc: Literature is books, plays, and poetry.
exam: Early American literature covers the poetry and stories from 1500 to 1800.

desc: A millennium is one thousand years.
exam: Stonehenge is believed to have been built about 5 millenniums ago.

desc: A myth is a traditional story that explains a culture’s history and beliefs.
exam: In Greece, there was a myth about a woman who had snakes for hair.

desc: To relate to something means to have a connection with it.
exam: A company’s plan usually relates to how much profit it can make.

desc: A religion is a belief in a god or gods.
exam: Their religion taught that people should forgive their enemies.

desc: A sum is a specific amount of money.
exam: He calculated the numbers to see what the sum of his bills would be.

desc: A teller is a person who works with a bank’s customers.
exam: The teller at the bank helped Kelly put money into a savings account.

desc: If someone is trustworthy, they are honest and truthful.
exam: Mary is one of the most trustworthy people I’ve ever met.

desc: To update something means to make it more modern.
exam: We need to update the programs on our computers.

desc: A vein is a tube in the body that carries blood toward the heart.
exam: The blue veins in my hand are just under my skin.

desc: Venom is a poisonous substance that comes from animals or plants.
exam: A snake’s venom can be used to cure the illnesses it creates.

desc: To promote someone means to raise them to a higher position or rank.
exam: After two years in the company, she was promoted to a manager.

desc: Charity is an act of giving help, usually money, to those who need it.
exam: Thanks to his friends’ charity, he had enough money to pay the rent.

desc: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling things.
exam: The new shopping mall increased the commerce in that section of town.

desc: To condemn someone means to give them a specific punishment.
exam: The judge condemned the criminal to five years in prison.

desc: If something is cozy, then it is comfortable, warm, and relaxing.
exam: The thick blanket made the bed very cozy.

desc: To deplete an amount of something means to use up all of it.
exam: All the driving he was doing was depleting his car’s fuel supply.

desc: An economy is the money and businesses of a country or region.
exam: The factory was good for the economy because it brought jobs to the area.

desc: An empire is a large group of countries ruled by an emperor or empress.
exam: The emperor built roads to make travel easier throughout the empire.

desc: Goods are anything that can be bought or sold.
exam: Shoes, hats, dresses and purses were the goods she wanted to buy.

desc: To heed something means to obey or follow it.
exam: You should heed the advice on the sign and not drive so fast.

desc: To hitchhike means to travel by asking for rides from passing vehicles.
exam: She didn’t have a car, so she hitchhiked several miles to her brother’s home.

desc: To mock someone means to tease them in a cruel way.
exam: The girls mocked Nancy because she was a new student.

desc: If someone is neutral, then they do not help either of the two fighting sides.
exam: The girl’s friend remained neutral while the couple was arguing.

desc: To persecute means to treat someone badly.
exam: Dan felt persecuted because he was smaller than the other boys at school.

desc: Pity is the feeling of sadness and kindness for those who are suffering.
exam: Because she had pity for the lost boy, she helped him find his parents.

desc: To reduce something means to make it less in size or number.
exam: When the store reduced its prices, people wanted to shop there.

desc: A scribe was a person whose job was to copy written works.
exam: In Ancient Egypt, scribes recorded important events.

desc: A temper is someone’s mood or a chance that they might get angry.
exam: She has a temper. Even the slightest mistakes make her angry.

desc: A throne is the special chair in which a ruler sits.
exam: Nobody except the king and queen sat in the thrones in the great hall.

desc: Unity is the state of people working together for a certain purpose.
exam: The project was finished early, thanks to the unity of the workers.

desc: A victor is a group or person that wins in a contest.
exam: At the end of the game, the blue team was the victor.

desc: If something is accurate, it is completely correct.
exam: The story in the newspaper wasn’t very accurate.

desc: To analyze something is to study it.
exam: The scientist will analyze the blood sample.

desc: An asteroid is a giant rock from outer space.
exam: In 1908, a giant asteroid hit Siberia.

desc: A controversy is a dispute about something that affects many people.
exam: There has been a lot of controversy over the judge’s decision.

desc: To evolve is to change over time.
exam: Many people think that humans evolved from animals.

desc: A factor is something that has an effect on the way another thing happens.
exam: Smoking is the main factor that causes lung cancer.

desc: If something is genetic, it is related to the genes in one’s body.
exam: The color of one’s eyes is genetic.

desc: A genome is the collection of all the genes in a living thing.
exam: Understanding the human genome may help cure many diseases.

desc: To be identical is to be the same as someone or something else.
exam: James and John are identical twins.

desc: An intellectual is a very smart person.
exam: We’ve always considered my Uncle Max the intellectual of the family.

desc: A majority of something is almost all of the people or things in that group.
exam: A majority of the people voted for Tom Smith in the election.

desc: A mammal is an animal that usually has hair and is not born from an egg.
exam: Even though it lives in the water, whales are actually mammals.

desc: To multiply is to increase in number.
exam: In the past year, the number of people at work multiplied by ten percent.

desc: Offspring are the children of a person or the babies of an animal.
exam: The dog’s offspring had the same color of fur as she did.

desc: A pesticide is a substance used to kill insects.
exam: The farmer sprayed his crops with a pesticide to keep bugs away.

desc: To regulate something is to control how it happens.
exam: The bank regulates how much money people can borrow from it.

desc: To reinforce something is to make it stronger.
exam: Peter reinforced his opinion with information from a book.

desc: If one is stricken by a disease or problem, they are badly affected by it.
exam: Mike was stricken with a horrible illness.

desc: If something is vast, it is very large.
exam: The wealthy man bought a vast amount of land in the countryside.

desc: A vegetarian is someone who does not eat any meat products.
exam: I became a vegetarian because I don’t like the taste of meat.

desc: To cherish something means to hold it as very important.
exam: I cherish this trophy I won.

desc: Compassion is a feeling of understanding for someone who is hurt or suffering.
exam: The veterinarian had compassion for the sick little puppy.

desc: Consent is permission to do something.
exam: Their mother gave the children consent to go outside and play.

desc: The core is the center of something.
exam: The rings of a tree start forming at its core.

desc: If someone is cunning, they are good at tricking people.
exam: The cunning child fooled his parents into thinking that he was kind.

desc: If someone is dizzy, then they feel off balance as if they will fall down.
exam: The pregnant woman was dizzy after standing up too quickly.

desc: Equilibrium is the balance between different forces.
exam: The sudden drop in prices upset the equilibrium of the economy.

desc: To foster a feeling or a skill means to help it develop.
exam: She helped foster a sense of calm in the little boy.

desc: To grind something means to break it into very small pieces or powder.
exam: She wanted to grind the beans, so she could brew some coffee.

desc: To growl means to make a deep, angry sound.
exam: The dog started to growl at the man walking by.

desc: Moderation is a state of being just enough but not too much.
exam: It is important to eat in moderation so that you can have a healthy body.

desc: A predator is an animal that kills and eats other animals.
exam: The peregrine falcon is a predator that eats fish.

desc: If someone is sane, they can think in a normal way.
exam: Oliver does not act like a sane person when he is angry.

desc: A saucer is a small round dish that you set a cup on.
exam: He placed the spoon on the saucer.

desc: To snatch something means to take it away with a quick motion.
exam: He was so hungry that he snatched an apple from a tree.

desc: To stagger means to move in an unsteady way and almost fall over.
exam: He staggered around after having too much to drink.

desc: To stumble means to put your foot down wrong so that you almost fall.
exam: He stumbled as he ran through the puddle.

desc: If someone is tense, they are worried something bad might happen.
exam: After the phone call, Monica was very tense.

desc: To tumble means to fall, often in a rolling way.
exam: He lost his balance while snowboarding and tumbled to the ground.

desc: To withhold something is to not give it to someone.
exam: They withheld all information until she paid her fine.

desc: An aircraft is a vehicle that flies in the sky, such as an airplane or helicopter.
exam: At the museum in the airport, you can see a lot of old aircraft.

desc: A celebrity is someone who is famous.
exam: It was the highlight of the evening when the celebrities arrived.

desc: Concrete is a substance made from stones.
exam: The man covered the ground with concrete.

desc: If someone is decisive, they make decisions quickly.
exam: Our boss is very decisive, so it did not take long to organize the project.

desc: If someone is esteemed, many people like or respect them.
exam: An esteemed scientist is coming to the university to talk about her discoveries.

desc: If something is ethical, it is the right thing to do.
exam: Many people believe that it is ethical to help others in need.

desc: If plants or animals are extinct, there are none left.
exam: There used to be dinosaurs all over the world, but now they are extinct.

desc: If a person or plant is hardy, it is strong and can live though difficult conditions.
exam: The farmer is a hardy man and doesn’t mind working outside.

desc: An institute is an organization that is interested in research or teaching.
exam: I am going to a lecture about ancient Rome at the Historical Institute.

desc: Jealousy is a feeling of wanting something that somebody else has.
exam: She felt a lot of jealousy when she saw Luke with two girls.

desc: To migrate means to move from one place to another.
exam: Many birds migrate to warmer countries in the winter.

desc: To nurture something means to care for it as it grows or develops.
exam: Robert nurtured his plants, and that is why they grow so well.

desc: If something is overhead, it is located above you.
exam: As we sat on top of the hill, a plane flew overhead.

desc: A principle is a belief about the correct way to behave.
exam: To maintain principles, it’s vital to watch, listen, and speak carefully.

desc: If a place is rural, it is in the countryside instead of the city.
exam: I want to live in a small house in a rural area.

desc: If a place is secluded, it is far away from any other place.
exam: There was a secluded bench in the park.

desc: A species is a type of plant or animal.
exam: There are 21 different species of butterfly in this forest.

desc: A swamp is a very wet area of land.
exam: There are lots of wild animals living in the swamp.

desc: To traverse means to move or travel through an area.
exam: The explorer traversed the desert alone on a camel.

desc: Zoology is a subject in which people study animals.
exam: Helen wants to study zoology because she has always liked animals.

desc: An assumption is something that you believe is true but cannot prove.
exam: I went to the cafeteria on the assumption that everyone would be there.

desc: Barley is a grain that is used for animal feed, health food and beer.
exam: The farmer grew barley to feed his cows in the winter.

desc: A beast is a large, dangerous animal.
exam: A lion is one of the fiercest beasts on Earth.

desc: A colonel is a military officer.
exam: James has been given a promotion in the army. He is now a colonel.

desc: If a disease is contagious, it is easily carried from one person to another.
exam: You must wear protective clothing because the patient’s illness is contagious.

desc: A corpse is a dead body of a human.
exam: After the accident, the corpse was taken to the hospital.

desc: A crisis is a situation that is extremely stressful or dangerous.
exam: The airport workers’ strike led to a crisis at the airport.

desc: To cure means to cause an illness or injury to end or disappear.
exam: My dentist cured me of my toothache.

desc: If something is deformed, it is not shaped normally and may appear ugly.
exam: Even though the carrot was deformed, it was still safe to eat.

desc: To discriminate means to judge people according to their looks.
exam: They discriminated against her because she was different.

desc: An embassy is where government officials work in a foreign country.
exam: If you lose your passport, you should contact the embassy.

desc: To extinguish a fire means to make it stop.
exam: Michael extinguished the small fire with the hose.

desc: Flint is a hard stone that people used to make weapons for hunting.
exam: There are a lot of flint tools in the museum.

desc: To harass someone means to annoy or trouble them.
exam: The children harassed their mother because they wanted her attention.

desc: To integrate means to join, communicate and socialize.
exam: Governments want immigrants to integrate with the population.

desc: If something is miniature, it is very small.
exam: The boy enjoys playing with his miniature train set in his bedroom.

desc: Nutrition is the process by which people use food to stay healthy.
exam: It is important to pay attention to nutrition if you want to be an athlete.

desc: If something happens promptly, it happens quickly or on time.
exam: Arrive promptly, or we won’t have time to discuss everything.

desc: A technician is a person who is skilled in electronic or mechanical work.
exam: I need to call the technician to help me with my computer.

desc: The tropics are the areas of land and sea close to the equator.
exam: People like to go to the tropics for vacation because it’s warm.

desc: If something is beneficial, it is good for you.
exam: Drinking milk everyday is beneficial to your bones.

desc: A birthplace is a place where a person is born or where something started.
exam: China is the birthplace of chopsticks.

desc: The capacity of something is the amount of things that can be put in it.
exam: The parking lot has reached its full capacity.

desc: If something is comparative, it is being judged based on something else.
exam: The money that John has is comparative to most other adults.

desc: If something is comprehensive, it has all the details about something else.
exam: The teacher gave us a comprehensive review for the exam.

desc: To conserve something is to protect it from being ruined or used completely.
exam: The group worked to conserve the beauty of Europe’s national parks.

desc: If something is crucial, it is extremely important to another thing.
exam: Clean air is crucial to the survival of humans, plants, and animals.

desc: Cumulative describes an increase by adding one after another.
exam: The cumulative snowfall in the area is 50 centimeters per year.

desc: To deposit something is to put it into a place or another thing.
exam: I deposited the money into my bank account.

desc: To distribute something is to give it to a number of people.
exam: The teacher distributed crayons and markers to his students.

desc: The equator is an imaginary line that splits the Earth into north and south.
exam: The equator crosses the northern part of South America.

desc: Exotic describes something unusual because it is from far away.
exam: Rebecca tried many exotic foods on her trip to Africa.

desc: If something is federal, it comes from the government of a country.
exam: Sometimes federal laws are different from state laws.

desc: A formation is the way that something is made.
exam: The formation of ice happens when water freezes.

desc: The frequency of something is the number of times that it happens.
exam: The frequency of rainstorms is very high, especially during the spring.

desc: An objective is a goal or plan that someone has.
exam: My objective this week is to finish my homework by 7:30 every night.

desc: Oxygen is a gas that all living things need to breathe.
exam: My aunt believes that the oxygen in the country is cleaner than in the city.

desc: A rainforest is a forest that is in a place where it rains very often.
exam: The rainforest is home to many animals.

desc: A strategy is a plan for how to do something.
exam: The team came up with a strategy to win the game.

desc: If an area is wooded, it is covered with trees.
exam: Jim and Ben decided to go hiking in the wooded area by the river.
vi: có nhiều cây cối rậm rạp

desc: Avail is help. It is often used in the achievement of a goal.
exam: His studying was to no avail because he failed the test.

desc: To expand is to become bigger in size.
exam: A balloon will expand as you blow air into it.

desc: To define means to clearly state, show, or explain what something is.
exam: People define success in many different ways.

desc: To dread is to be afraid of something that could, or is going to, happen.
exam: I dread the idea that I will not get into college.

desc: If something is fundamental, it is a basic part of something.
exam: The fundamental rules of basketball are easy.

desc: If something is horrifying, it is frightening and very unpleasant.
exam: There was a horrifying car accident today.

desc: If someone is incredulous about something, they do not believe that it is true.
exam: She was incredulous that monkeys could ever drive a car.

desc: To linger is to last for a long time.
exam: The smell of fresh cookies lingered in the bakery.

desc: An organism is a living thing, especially a very small one.
exam: We studied the organism on the microscope.

desc: To paraphrase is to make someone else’s writing or speech shorter.
exam: The students were asked to paraphrase the story they just heard.

desc: A plague is a serious disease that quickly spreads to many people.
exam: A plague in Europe killed millions of people.

desc: If something happens presently, it is happening right now.
exam: Presently, our profits are good, but by next year we can do even better.

desc: If something is random, it happens without any pattern or reason.
exam: Young children often ask random questions.

desc: A riot is a crowd that reacts to bad news by violently breaking laws.
exam: A riot broke out after the candidate lost the election.

desc: To scribble is to write something quickly without caring about how it looks.
exam: I scribbled a rough diagram of our plan and gave it to him.

desc: A shrine is a religious building built to honor a person, event, or god.
exam: He prayed at the shrine for an hour.

desc: Solitude is the state of being totally alone.
exam: John lives a life of solitude because he doesn’t get along well with people.

desc: If a contrast is stark, then the things being compared are utterly different.
exam: There is a stark contrast between their test scores.

desc: To summon a person is to ask them to come to you.
exam: We summoned the doctor as soon as we noticed she was sick.

desc: To worsen is to get worse.
exam: The weather suddenly worsened, and we had to stay inside.

desc: An automobile is a car.
exam: The first automobiles were very different from the ones that exist today.

desc: A candidate is a person who is competing to win something such as a job.
exam: Alice is the best candidate for the job.

desc: If something is confidential, it must be kept secret.
exam: The information from the meeting is confidential.

desc: If something is corporate, it is related to a large business.
exam: Tom enjoys working in the corporate world.

desc: To enhance something is to make it better.
exam: Amy’s blue shirt really enhances the color of her eyes.

desc: An era is a period of time that has something special about it.
exam: During the medieval era, knights wore protective armor.

desc: A guideline is a rule about how to do something.
exam: Before they began the project, the teacher gave them some guidelines.

desc: To incorporate is to add something to another thing.
exam: I decided to incorporate a new ingredient into my cake recipe.

desc: To interact is to talk to or do something with another person.
exam: The kids began to interact when the adults left the room.

desc: An interval is the time between two things happening.
exam: Tony rested for brief intervals while he worked in the yard.

desc: If something is mobile, it can be moved easily.
exam: Mobile phones are popular because you can take them anywhere.

desc: To modify something is to change it a little bit.
exam: I modified my outfit by adding a belt to it.

desc: If two things are parallel, they are the same distance away from each other.
exam: There are two yellow parallel lines dividing both sides of traffic.

desc: A phenomenon is something that can be seen as it is happening.
exam: I was amazed when I saw the phenomenon of shooting stars.

desc: To pollute means to make air, water, or land dirty, unclean, or foul.
exam: The careless factory polluted the river with chemicals.

desc: To ridicule is to make fun of something in a mean way.
exam: The other students ridicule Peter’s foreign accent.

desc: If something is solar, it is related to the sun.
exam: Using solar energy is good for the environment.

desc: A territory is a piece of land that belongs to a country but isn’t a state.
exam: Gibraltar is a territory of Great Britain.

desc: A tournament is a competition, usually with many people participating.
exam: My dad is playing in a golf tournament tomorrow.

desc: Transportation is any type of vehicle that can carry people or things.
exam: I don’t have a car, so my normal transportation is the train.

desc: A bill is a statement of money owed for goods or a service.
exam: I have so many bills that I do not know how to pay for them all.

desc: A boundary is the line where one area of land stops, and another begins.
exam: This fence shows the boundary between our yard and yours.

desc: Chaos is a situation that is confusing and not ordered.
exam: His presentation was in chaos. I couldn’t understand what he meant.

desc: If a person is consistent, they keep the same behavior or attitude.
exam: Sara comes in every day and is our most consistent worker.

desc: A cyclone is a large storm with heavy rain and winds that spin in a circle.
exam: Hundreds of homes were damaged by the cyclone.

desc: If someone or something is doomed, they are going to fail or be destroyed.
exam: Since I spent all my money, my date with Jane is doomed.

desc: An heir is a person who receives money or property of someone who dies.
exam: The princess was the heir to the king and queen’s throne.

desc: If something is martial, it is related to fighting or war.
exam: Karate is a martial art that began many years ago in Japan.

desc: If food is organic, it is grown without adding chemicals to it.
exam: The organic carrots are more expensive, but they’re better for you.

desc: Poultry is a bird, such as a chicken, that is used for meat and eggs.
exam: He raises poultry and sells their meat for extra money.

desc: To scramble is to move somewhere quickly and desperately.
exam: The hikers scrambled down the side of the hill.

desc: A sergeant is a soldier or police officer of middle rank.
exam: He was promoted to sergeant after a year in the army.

desc: If you describe something as sheer, it is complete and very strong.
exam: I was impressed by her sheer dedication to jogging.

desc: A stance is an attitude about an issue that someone states clearly.
exam: My stance is that using oil and gas is bad for the environment.

desc: A telegraph is a method of sending electric messages on wires.
exam: In the 1900s, the telegraph was the fastest way to send a message.

desc: Textile is cloth that has been woven or knitted.
exam: The blue textile was going to be used to make blouses.

desc: A tornado is a tube-shaped formation of air that spins very quickly.
exam: During a tornado, the safest place to be is underground.

desc: A typhoon is a large tropical storm that moves in circles.
exam: Thousands of people lost electricity after a typhoon hit Australia.

desc: To wail is to show sadness by crying loudly.
exam: The baby wailed because it was hungry.

desc: A wardrobe is the collection of all of a person’s clothing.
exam: She bought some new clothes to expand her wardrobe.
